text: Number 497, Willard H. Phillips, Petitioner, versus Joseph -- versus New York.
If it please the Court.

Your Honors, you've just enjoyed a -- an extraordinarily fair statement of the facts in the record from Mr. Schober as to the basic facts in his presentation, I have no quarrel.Some of the inferences that he draws principally in his briefs more or so than here on the argument this afternoon, I do quarrel.
What is the police -- 28 police department?
There are 28 separate police departments in the county, Your Honor.
Oh, I know.
Well, some of the departments are quite small.
(Voice Overlap) --
-- more than uniform patrol groups but some of the departments like the county police have seven or eight precincts maybe 150 or 200 men in each precinct.
Is the department a functional division of (Voice Overlap) --
A functional division --
I see.
-- and with independent authority.
About 10 o'clock?
About 9 o'clock, Your Honor.
9 o'clock.
The testimony of Rouffet is not too clear.
They were -- the -- when -- through the inference that they were rather waiting for the return from these tests, isn't that right?
I don't believe so, Your Honor.
Yes.
-- whether Inspector -- when Inspector Pribell finished these test.
I thought it was -- I thought (Inaudible) what is his name?
Dr. (Inaudible)
I thought he testified that by 8 o'clock, they had it, didn't they?
By 8 o'clock they had taken the samples but then --
And they have to have these arguments (Inaudible)
That is right, Your Honor.
All were negative, were they?
All were negative, Your Honor.
Mr. Heneghan, you said a minute ago that the murder investigation didn't begin or until about 9 o'clock, is that right?
Well, I would say the questioning --
Questioning, that the --
-- in a murder investigation.
Didn't begin until 9, the fact that there was murder to be investigated was clear at 5.
That is true, Your Honor.
And how do you account for the hours between 5 or 9?
The record -- the testimony of both Detectives Stock the homicide squad and Inspector Pribell show that once the body was located, they proceeded to the scene of the crime.
The body was found about at 5 o'clock, petitioner --
And they were -- the body was discovered by a railroad worker around 4 o'clock.
No.
It was until sometime after 5 apparently, that Stock and Pribell arrived at the scene.
And then -- then they took the body, an investigation -- an autopsy was made of the body, wasn't there?
Yes.
And then there were also various samples of necessary evidence to make test of the child's body or what had taken place there, wasn't it?
Yes.
Well, I suppose that accounts to intervening time?
Well, there, again, the record isn't clear as to --
But I say that probably account, one can't tell.
You can't tell --
There isn't a timetable in the record, is there?
No, there is not Your Honor.
I mean there is an -- a timetable to be worked out to the record.
Yes.
Approximately.
-- but not for all.
Yes.
I believe -- I was talking about the interruptions or the lapses in the questioning of the petitioner as a suspect in a murder.
What time was that please?
That must -- sometime between 3:30 and 4:30 apparently was the questioning conducted by the chief of detectives.
They are not -- they knew nothing of the body at that time.
Yes they did, Your Honor.
Oh, a.m.
A.m.
Oh, yes.
